Hi Andy,

in my project file (MSVC 2005) I added "ode.lib opengl32.lib 
glu=
32.lib" only. I didn't have to recompile Irrlicht, just ODE. 
Make sure (in=
 the C++/Code Generation options) that you use "Multi-
Threaded DLL" as a r=
untime library. (in Release mode). 

Try these suggestions. It this doesn't=
 work, you can write me an e-
mail (spookey@...) or find me in Skype (sp=
ookey85), to think of 
something and find a way to compile this stuff and t=
hen note how to 
set up the environment so everyone can compile. 

Peter

-=

ski"

> > > >
> > > > Hello there, 
> > > =
> 
> > > > I am using the following CPPN model for the substrate: 
> > > > =

> > > > Inputs: X1, Y1, X2, Y2, BIAS
> > > > Outputs: Weight, Node-Bias, N=
ode-Time_Constant
> > > > 
> > > > The time constant range is [0.5 .. 5.0] =
and the weight/node-
> bias 
> > > range 
> > > > within the substrate in [=
-8.0 .. 8.0]. 
> > > > The weight range in the CPPN is unbounded. 
> > > > =

> > > > The node-specific outputs are computed using (X1, Y1, BIAS) 
and 
=
> > > the 
> > > > others set to 0.
> > > > 
> > > > The activation functio=
ns used are plain sigmoid, gaussian, 
and 
> > > sine. 
> > > > The CTRNN s=
ubstrate activates with 0.02 timestep and it is 
used 
> > to 
> > > > cont=
rol a 3D humanoid model, simulated in a physical 
> environment 
> > > (usi=
ng 
> > > > Open Dynamics Engine http://www.ode.org ). 
> > > > 
> > > > Th=
e thing I notice, is the following: 
> > > > 
> > > > The first networks ar=
e simple, and so the connective patterns 
> > are. 
> > > But 
> > > > the =
node biases and time constants are also simple. When I 
> watch 
> > > an 
=
> > > > animaion of the activation changing in the substrate, it 
looks 
> =
> > like it 
> > > > exibits a pattern. The simplest I've seen can be descr=
ibed as 
a 
> > > mexican 
> > > > wave travelling across the hidden nodes.=
 
> > > > As the CPPNs complexify, so do the activity patterns 
exibited. 
=
> > > When 
> > > > using regular NEAT for the problem of keeping the human=
oid 
> model 
> > > > balanced, it has moslty erratic behaviour, and the lu=
cky ones 
> > > (with 
> > > > high fitness) usually find a way to trick th=
e system and stay 
> in 
> > a 
> > > > balanced position forever, without =
moving at all. 
> > > > But when HyperNEAT is used for this, it looks reall=
y 
> interesting 
> > > and.. 
> > > > natural! The model is trying to bala=
nce using its arms, and 
it 
> is 
> > > > moving.. It looks like a drunk g=
uy, but you note the 
> difference. 
> > > > I've arranged the nodes in a g=
eometric way.. Let me explain - 
> the 
> > > left 
> > > > and right arm's=
 outputs are separated in the left and right 
in 
> > the 
> > > > substrat=
e space, and close to each other. So do the legs. The 
> > > hidden 
> > > =
> nodes are in the center in a star/cirlular shape. I also 
> included 
> >=
 > 3 
> > > > inputs (head velocity) in the center around 0.0, but with 
> =
smaller 
> > > > radius than the ring of hidden nodes. 
> > > > 
> > > > Pe=
ter
